title: Tunstall Forest Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Simon Leatherdale / Beech pollards in Tunstall Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Beech pollards in Tunstall Forest. Veteran Beech pollards in "six acre covert"

images.title: Jon Hopkins / Deer on a Forest Track in Tunstall Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Deer on a Forest Track. The nice wide track is flanked by gorse bushes

images.title: Simon Leatherdale / Pond - Tunstall Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This pond in the forest is a good breeding site for Frog and Toad, the surrounding area is excellent for seeing Adders (the trees in the background are Corsican pines).

images.title: Simon Leatherdale / Crag pit - Tunstall Forest., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: One of many crag pits that dot the landscape in this area.

images.title: Simon Leatherdale / Tumulus in Tunstall Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Tumulus in the forest. This Bronze age tumulus (on the right) is set on top of a ridge with open views to the north and west and mature Scots Pine to the south west. The remainder of the vista is young (post '87 gale) pine.

images.title: Simon Leatherdale / Woodlark area in Tunstall Forest., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Woodlark area. This is one of several areas kept open in Tunstall forest SSSI to encourage Woodlark and Nightjar populations.

images.title: John Goldsmith / Snape Maltings viewed from Tunstall Forest., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Snape Maltings viewed from the firest. The maltings buildings, now a concert and shopping centre, are just visible to the left of the tree above the post. The photograph was taken from a footpath on the edge of the forest.

images.title: Simon Leatherdale / Veteran Oaks and Bluebells - Tunstall Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Nice view of some veteran Oaks and Bluebells amidst the conifers

description: This large forest in Suffolk has miles of good footpaths and a 10 mile red graded single-track mountain bike trail. The waymarked route is called the Viking Trail and is a narrow flowing singletrack running through the trees, with twists, berms and some short climbs. It's a fun ride and not too challenging though there are some technically tricky bits. The ride starts at the car park off Tunstall Road towards the northern end of the forest. This mountain bike route is designed for cyclists but walkers can easily pick up the forest footpaths from the same start location. You can walk down to Tunstall Common and then continue south to the little village of Chillesford for refreshments. From here you can pick up the Suffolk Coast Path to take you back into the forest and then head west to return to the car park.
